DOC.HEAD: Two Main Sikh Parties Stay Away From Political Meeting on Punjab
DOC.TEXT: The government Sunday held a meeting of political parties to discuss Sikh separatism in Punjab but the two main Sikh parties stayed away, demanding an investigation into alleged human rights abuses. Prime Minister V.P. Singh presided over the meeting, his first political initiative to address Sikh militants' demands for an independent homeland in the northern farming state. More than 7,000 people have died in an 8-year-old separatist movement in the region. About 40 leaders from 21 parties attended the meeting, and they later issued a statement that was endorsed by all but one of the parties. ``While serious efforts to find a political solution continue, the people must be reassured that there would be no letup in the fight against terrorism,'' the statement said. Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party dissociated itself from the statement, saying it could not be considered a consensus document since Congress had no part in drafting it. Punjab's two main Sikh parties, the Akali Dal-Mann and Akali Dal-Badal, boycotted the meeting. Before discussions can be held, they said, tensions must be eased in the state and police must be investigated for alleged human rights violations. Akali Dal-Mann Party, known to be supported by Sikh extremist groups, won nine of the state's 13 parliamentary seats in last month's general elections. The conference condemned the daily killings in Punjab but made only one specific recommendation _ repealing a law that gives the government broad powers to detain suspected extremists. The law was passed by Gandhi's government and officials at the meeting said the recommendation to repeal the statute probably was the reason the Congress Party refused to endorse the joint statement. Congress issued a separate statement that said the government asked the participants to reach a consensus without stating its own position. Gandhi was forced to resign as prime minister after the party failed to maintain a majority in Parliament following the general elections. Singh took office on Dec. 2. He visited Sikhism's holiest shrine, the Golden Temple, five days later but described the visit as personal. Nonetheless, he was the first prime minister to visit the temple in five years and the trip was seen as an astute move to assuage Sikhs angered by an army raid on the shrine in June, 1984. The attack was ordered by Indira Gandhi, the former prime minister's mother and predecessor, to flush out Sikh extremists entrenched inside. She was assassinated four months later by two Sikh bodyguards. Anti-Sikh riots ensued nationwide and more than 3,000 Sikhs were killed. Militants say India's Hindu-dominated government discriminates against Sikhs socially and culturally and wants an independent homeland in Punjab. Sikhs are in a slight majority in the state, which borders Pakistan. Nationwide they make up 2 percent of the 880 million people, while Hindus make up 80 percent of the population.
